hither: here he does but repair it. I know he
will come in our shadow, to scatter his crowns in the
sun.

sp.speaker: Boult
sp.ab: Well, if we had of every nation a traveller, we
should lodge them with this sign.

sp.speaker: Bawd
sp.ab: Pray you, come hither awhile. You have fortunes
coming upon you. Mark me: you must seem to do
that fearfully which you commit willingly,
despise profit where you have most gain. To weep
that you live as ye do makes pity in your lovers:
seldom but that pity begets you a good opinion, and
that opinion a mere profit.

sp.speaker: Marina
sp.ab: I understand you not.

sp.speaker: Boult
sp.ab: O, take her home, mistress, take her home: these
blushes of hers must be quenched with some present
practice.

sp.speaker: Bawd
sp.ab: Thou sayest true, i' faith so they must; for
your bride goes to that with shame which is her way to
go with warrant.

sp.speaker: Boult
sp.ab: 'Faith, some do, and some do not. But, mistress, if I
have bargained for the joint, â

sp.speaker: Bawd
sp.ab: Thou mayst cut a morsel off the spit.

sp.speaker: Boult
sp.ab: I may so.

sp.speaker: Bawd
sp.ab: Who should deny it? Come, young one, I like the
manner of your garments well.

sp.speaker: Boult
sp.ab: Ay, by my faith, they shall not be changed yet.

sp.speaker: Bawd
sp.ab: Boult, spend thou that in the town: report what
a sojourner we have; you'll lose nothing by
custom. When nature framed this piece, she meant
thee a good turn; therefore say what a paragon
she is, and thou hast the harvest out of thine own
report.

sp.speaker: Boult
sp.ab: I warrant you, mistress, thunder shall not so
awake the beds of eels as my giving out her
beauty stirs up the lewdly inclined. I'll bring home
some to-night.

sp.speaker: Bawd
sp.ab: Come your ways; follow me.

sp.speaker: Marina
sp.l: If fires be hot, knives sharp, or waters deep,
Untied I still my virgin knot will keep.
Diana, aid my purpose!

sp.speaker: Bawd
sp.ab: What have we to do with Diana? Pray you, will you go
with us?

div.head: Act 4, Scene 3
div.stage: Tarsus. A room in Clean's house.
Enter CLEON and DIONYZA.

sp.speaker: Dionyza
sp.l: Why, are you foolish? Can it be undone?

sp.speaker: Cleon
sp.l: O Dionyza, such a piece of slaughter
The sun and moon ne'er looked upon!

sp.speaker: Dionyza
sp.l: I think you'll turn a child again.

sp.speaker: Cleon
sp.l: Were I chief lord of all this spacious world,
I'ld give it to undo the deed. O lady,
Much less in blood than virtue, yet a princess
To equal any single crown a' the earth
I' the justice of compare! O villain Leonine!
Whom thou hast poisoned too:
If thou hadst drunk to him, 't had been a kindness
Becoming well thy fact: what canst thou say
When noble Pericles shall demand his child?

sp.speaker: Dionyza
sp.l: That she is dead. Nurses are not the fates,
To foster it, not ever to preserve.
She died at night; I'll say so. Who can cross it?
Unless you play the pious innocent,
And for an honest attribute cry out
âShe died by foul play.â

sp.speaker: Cleon
sp.l: O, go to. Well, well,
Of all the faults beneath the heavens, the gods
Do like this worst.

sp.speaker: Dionyza
sp.l: Be one of those that thinks
The petty wrens of Tarsus will fly hence,
And open this to Pericles. I do shame
To think of what a noble strain you are,
And of how coward a spirit.

sp.speaker: Cleon
sp.l: To such proceeding
Who ever but his approbation added,
Though not his prime consent, he did not flow
From honourable courses.

sp.speaker: Dionyza
sp.l: Be it so, then:
Yet none does know, but you, how she came dead,
Nor none can know, Leonine being gone.
She did distain my child, and stood between
Her and her fortunes: none would look on her,
But cast their gazes on Marina's face;
Whilst ours was blurted at and held a malkin
Not worth the time of day. It pierced me thorough;
And though you call my course unnatural,
You not your child well loving, yet I find
It greets me as an enterprise of kindness
Performed to your sole daughter.

sp.speaker: Cleon
sp.l: Heavens forgive it!

sp.speaker: Dionyza
sp.l: And as for Pericles,
What should he say? We wept after her hearse,
And yet we mourn: her monument
Is almost finished, and her epitaphs
In glittering golden characters express
A general praise to her, and care in us
At whose expense 'tis done.

sp.speaker: Cleon
sp.l: Thou art like the harpy,
Which, to betray, dost, with thine angel's face,
Seize with thine eagle's talons.

sp.speaker: Dionyza
sp.l: You are like one that superstitiously
Do swear to the gods that winter kills the flies:
But yet I know you'll do as I advise. Exeunt.

div.head: Act 4, Scene 4
div.stage: Enter GOWER, before the monument of MARINA at Tarsus.

sp.speaker: Gower
sp.l: Thus time we waste, and long leagues make short;
Sail seas in cockles, have an wish but for't;
Making, to take our imagination,
From bourn to bourn, region to region.
By you being pardoned, we commit no crime
To use one language in each several clime
Where our scenes seems to live. I do beseech you
To learn of me, who stand i' the gaps to teach you,
The stages of our story. Pericles
Is now again thwarting the wayward seas,
Attended on by many a lord and knight,
To see his daughter, all his life's delight.
Old Helicanus goes along. Behind
Is left to govern it, you bear in mind
Old Escanes, whom Helicanus late
Advanced in time to great and high estate,
Well-sailing ships and bounteous winds have brought
This king to Tarsus, â think his pilot thought;
So with his steerage shall your thoughts grow on, â
To fetch his daughter home, who first is gone.
Like motes and shadows see them move awhile;
Your ears unto your eyes I'll reconcile.
sp.stage: Enter PERICLES, at one door, with all his train; CLEON and DIONYZA, at the other.
CLEON shows PERICLES the tomb; whereat PERICLES makes lamentation, puts on sack-cloth,
and in a mighty passion departs. Then exeunt CLEON and DIONYZA.
sp.l: See how belief may suffer by foul show!
This borrowed passion stands for true old woe;
And Pericles, in sorrow all devoured,
With sighs shot through, and biggest tears o'ershowered,
Leaves Tarsus and again embarks. He swears
Never to wash his face, nor cut his hairs:
He puts on sackcloth, and to sea. He bears
A tempest, which his mortal vessel tears,
And yet he rides it out. Now please you wit
The epitaph is for Marina writ
By wicked Dionyza. Reads the inscription on Marina's monument.
âThe fairest, sweet'st, and best lies here,
Who withered in her spring of year.
She was of Tyrus the king's daughter,
On whom foul death hath made this slaughter;
Marina was she called; and at her birth,
Thetis, being proud, swallowed some part a' the earth:
Therefore the earth, fearing to be o'erflowed,
Hath Thetis' birth-child on the heavens bestowed:
Wherefore she does, and swears she'll never stint,
Make raging battery upon shores of flint.â
No visor does become black villainy
So well as soft and tender flattery.
Let Pericles believe his daughter's dead,
And bear his courses to be ordered
By Lady Fortune; while our scene must play
His daughter's woe and heavy well-a-day
In her unholy service. Patience, then,
And think you now are all in Mytilene. Exit.

div.head: Act 4, Scene 5
div.stage: Mytilene. A street before the brothel.
Enter, from the brothel, two Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: First Gentleman
sp.ab: Did you ever hear the like?

sp.speaker: Second Gentleman
sp.ab: No, nor never shall do in such a place as this, she
being once gone.

sp.speaker: First Gentleman
sp.ab: But to have divinity preached there! did you ever
dream of such a thing?

sp.speaker: Second Gentleman
sp.ab: No, no. Come, I am for no more bawdy-houses: shall's
go hear the vestals sing?

sp.speaker: First Gentleman
sp.ab: I'll do any thing now that is virtuous; but I am out
of the road of rutting for ever.

div.head: Act 4, Scene 6
div.stage: The same. A room in the brothel.
Enter Pandar, Bawd, and BOULT.

sp.speaker: Pandar
sp.ab: Well, I had rather than twice the worth of her she
had ne'er come here.

sp.speaker: Bawd
sp.ab: Fie, fie upon her! she's able to freeze the god
Priapus, and undo a whole generation. We must
either get her ravished, or be rid of her. When
she should do for clients her fitment, and do
me the kindness of our profession, she has me
her quirks, her reasons, her master reasons,
her prayers, her knees; that she would make a puritan
of the devil, if he should cheapen a kiss of her.

sp.speaker: Boult
sp.ab: 'Faith, I must ravish her, or she'll disfurnish
us of all our cavaliers, and make our swearers
priests.

sp.speaker: Pandar
sp.ab: Now, the pox upon her green-sickness for me!

sp.speaker: Bawd
sp.ab: 'Faith, there's no way to be rid on't but by
the way to the pox. Here comes the Lord Lysimachus
disguised.

sp.speaker: Boult
sp.ab: We should have both lord and lown, if the peevish
baggage would but give way to customers.

sp.speaker: Lysimachus
sp.ab: How now! How a dozen of virginities?

sp.speaker: Bawd
sp.ab: Now, the gods to bless your honour!

sp.speaker: Boult
sp.ab: I am glad to see your honour in good health.

sp.speaker: Lysimachus
sp.ab: You may so; 'tis the better for you that your
resorters stand upon sound legs. How now!
wholesome iniquity have you that a man may deal
withal, and defy the surgeon?

sp.speaker: Bawd
sp.ab: We have here one, sir, if she would â but there never
came her like in Mytilene.

sp.speaker: Lysimachus
sp.ab: If she'ld do the deeds of darkness, thou wouldst say.

sp.speaker: Bawd
sp.ab: Your honour knows what 'tis to say well enough.

sp.speaker: Lysimachus
sp.ab: Well, call forth, call forth.

sp.speaker: Boult
sp.ab: For flesh and blood, sir, white and red, you
shall see a rose; and she were a rose indeed, if she
had but â

sp.speaker: Lysimachus
sp.ab: What, prithee?

sp.speaker: Boult
sp.ab: O, sir, I can be modest.

sp.speaker: Lysimachus
sp.ab: That dignifies the renown of a bawd, no less
than it gives a good report to a number to be chaste.

sp.speaker: Bawd
sp.ab: Here comes that which grows to the stalk; never
plucked yet, I can assure you.
Is she not a fair creature?

sp.speaker: Lysimachus
sp.ab: 'Faith, she would serve after a long voyage at sea.
Well, there's for you: leave us.

sp.speaker: Bawd
sp.ab: I beseech your honour, give me leave: a word, and I'll
have done presently.

sp.speaker: Lysimachus
sp.ab: I beseech you, do.

sp.speaker: Bawd
sp.ab: First, I would have you note, this is an honourable
man.

sp.speaker: Marina
sp.ab: I desire to find him so, that I may worthily note
him.

sp.speaker: Bawd
sp.ab: Next, he's the governor of this country, and a man
whom I am bound to.

sp.speaker: Marina
sp.ab: If he govern the country, you are bound to him
indeed; but how honourable he is in that, I know not.

sp.speaker: Bawd
sp.ab: Pray you, without any more virginal fencing,
will you use him kindly? He will line your apron with
gold.

sp.speaker: Marina
sp.ab: What he will do graciously, I will thankfully
receive.

sp.speaker: Lysimachus
sp.ab: Haâ you done?

sp.speaker: Bawd
sp.ab: My lord, she's not paced yet: you must take some
pains to work her to your manage. Come, we will leave
his honour and her together. Go thy ways.

sp.speaker: Lysimachus
sp.ab: Now, pretty one, how long have you been at this
trade?

sp.speaker: Marina
sp.ab: What trade, sir?

sp.speaker: Lysimachus
sp.ab: Why, I cannot name't but I shall offend.

sp.speaker: Marina
sp.ab: I cannot be offended with my trade. Please you to
name it.

sp.speaker: Lysimachus
sp.ab: How long have you been of this profession?

sp.speaker: Marina
sp.ab: E'er since I can remember?

sp.speaker: Lysimachus
sp.ab: Did you go to't so young? Were you a gamester at five
or at seven?

sp.speaker: Marina
sp.ab: Earlier too, sir, if now I be one.

sp.speaker: Lysimachus
sp.ab: Why, the house you dwell in proclaims you to be a
creature of sale.

sp.speaker: Marina
sp.ab: Do you know this house to be a place of such
resort, and will come into't? I hear say you're
of honourable parts, and are the governor of this
place.

sp.speaker: Lysimachus
sp.ab: Why, hath your principal made known unto you who I am?

sp.speaker: Marina
sp.ab: Who is my principal?

sp.speaker: Lysimachus
sp.ab: Why, your herb-woman; she that sets seeds and
roots of shame and iniquity. O, you have heard
something of my power, and so stand aloof for
more serious wooing. But I protest to thee,
pretty one, my authority shall not see thee, or
else look friendly upon thee. Come, bring me to some
private place: come, come.

sp.speaker: Marina
sp.l: If you were born to honour, show it now;
If put upon you, make the judgement good
That thought you worthy of it.

sp.speaker: Lysimachus
sp.l: How's this? how's this? Some more; be sage.

sp.speaker: Marina
sp.l: For me,
That am a maid, though most ungentle fortune
Have placed me in this sty, where, since I came,
Diseases have been sold dearer than physic.
That the gods
Would set me free from this unhallowed place,
Though they did change me to the meanest bird
That flies i' the purer air!

sp.speaker: Lysimachus
sp.l: I did not think
Thou couldst have spoke so well; ne'er dreamed thou couldst.
Had I brought hither a corrupted mind,
Thy speech had altered it. Hold, here's gold for thee:
Persever in that clear way thou goest,
And the gods strengthen thee!

sp.speaker: Marina
sp.l: The good gods preserve you!

sp.speaker: Lysimachus
sp.l: For me, be you thoughten
That I came with no ill intent; for to me
The very doors and windows savour vilely.
Fare thee well. Thou art a piece of virtue, and
I doubt not but thy training hath been noble.
Hold, here's more gold for thee.
A curse upon him, die he like a thief,
That robs thee of thy goodness! If thou dost
Hear from me, it shall be for thy good. Re-enter BOULT.

sp.speaker: Boult
sp.l: I beseech your honour, one piece for me.

sp.speaker: Lysimachus
sp.l: Avaunt, thou damned doorkeeper!
Your house, but for this virgin that doth prop it,
Would sink and overwhelm you. Away! Exit.

sp.speaker: Boult
sp.ab: How's this? We must take another course with
you. If your peevish chastity, which is not
worth a breakfast in the cheapest country under
the cope, shall undo a whole household, let me be
gelded like a spaniel. Come your ways.

sp.speaker: Marina
sp.ab: Whither would you have me?

sp.speaker: Boult
sp.ab: I must have your maidenhead taken off, or the
common hangman shall execute it. Come your ways.
We'll have no more gentlemen driven away. Come your
ways, I say.

sp.speaker: Bawd
sp.ab: How now! what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Boult
sp.ab: Worse and worse, mistress; she has here spoken holy
words to the Lord Lysimachus.

sp.speaker: Bawd
sp.ab: O abominable!

sp.speaker: Boult
sp.ab: She makes our profession as it were to stink afore
the face of the gods.

sp.speaker: Bawd
sp.ab: Marry, hang her up for ever!

sp.speaker: Boult
sp.ab: The nobleman would have dealt with her like a
nobleman, and she sent him away as cold as a
snowball; saying his prayers too.

sp.speaker: Bawd
sp.ab: Boult, take her away; use her at thy pleasure:
crack the glass of her virginity, and make the rest
malleable.

sp.speaker: Boult
sp.ab: An if she were a thornier piece of ground than she
is, she shall be ploughed.

sp.speaker: Marina
sp.ab: Hark, hark, you gods!

sp.speaker: Bawd
sp.ab: She conjures: away with her! Would she had never
come within my doors! Marry, hang you! She's
born to undo us. Will you not go the way of
womenkind? Marry, come up, my dish of chastity with
rosemary and bays!

sp.speaker: Boult
sp.ab: Come, mistress; come your ways with me.

sp.speaker: Marina
sp.ab: Whither wilt thou have me?

sp.speaker: Boult
sp.ab: To take from you the jewel you hold so dear.

sp.speaker: Marina
sp.ab: Prithee, tell me one thing first.

sp.speaker: Boult
sp.ab: Come now, your one thing.

sp.speaker: Marina
sp.ab: What canst thou wish thine enemy to be?

sp.speaker: Boult
sp.ab: Why, I could wish him to be my master, or rather, my
mistress.

sp.speaker: Marina
sp.l: Neither of these are so bad as thou art,
Since they do better thee in their command.
Thou hold'st a place, for which the pained'st fiend
Of hell would not in reputation change:
Thou art the damned doorkeeper to every
Coistrel that comes inquiring for his Tib;
To the choleric fisting of every rogue
Thy ear is liable, thy food is such
As hath been belched on by infected lungs.

sp.speaker: Boult
sp.ab: What would you have me do? go to the wars, would
you? where a man may serve seven years for the
loss of a leg, and have not money enough in the end
to buy him a wooden one?

sp.speaker: Marina
sp.l: Do any thing but this thou doest. Empty
Old receptacles, or common shores, of filth;
Serve by indenture to the common hangman:
Any of these ways are yet better than this;
For what thou professest, a baboon, could he speak,
Would own a name too dear. That the gods
Would safely deliver me from this place!
Here, here's gold for thee.
If that thy master would gain by me,
Proclaim that I can sing, weave, sew, and dance,
With other virtues, which I'll keep from boast;
And will undertake all these to teach.
I doubt not but this populous city will
Yield many scholars.

sp.speaker: Boult
sp.ab: But can you teach all this you speak of?

sp.speaker: Marina
sp.l: Prove that I cannot, take me home again,
And prostitute me to the basest groom
That doth frequent your house.

sp.speaker: Boult
sp.ab: Well, I will see what I can do for thee: if I can
place thee, I will.

sp.speaker: Marina
sp.ab: But amongst honest women.

sp.speaker: Boult
sp.ab: 'Faith, my acquaintance lies little amongst
them. But since my master and mistress hath
bought you, there's no going but by their consent:
therefore I will make them acquainted with your
purpose, and I doubt not but I shall find them
tractable enough. Come, I'll do for thee what I can;
come your ways.

div.head: Act 5, Chorus 1
div.stage: Enter GOWER.

sp.speaker: Gower
sp.l: Marina thus the brothel scapes, and chances
Into an honest house, our story says.
She sings like one immortal, and she dances
As goddess-like to her admired lays;
Deep clerks she dumbs; and with her neele composes
Nature's own shape, of bud, bird, branch, or berry,
That even her art sisters the natural roses;
Her inkle, silk, twin with the rubied cherry:
That pupils lacks she none of noble race,
Who pour their bounty on her; and her gain
She gives the cursed bawd. Here we her place;
And to her father turn our thoughts again,
Where we left him, on the sea. We there him lost;
Where, driven before the winds, he is arrived
Here where his daughter dwells; and on this coast
Suppose him now at anchor. The city strived
God Neptune's annual feast to keep: from whence
Lysimachus our Tyrian ship espies,
His banners sable, trimmed with rich expense;
And to him in his barge with fervour hies.
In your supposing once more put your sight
Of heavy Pericles; think this his bark:
Where what is done in action, more, if might,
Shall be discovered; please you, sit and hark. Exit.

div.head: Act 5, Scene 1
div.stage: On board Pericles' ship, off Mytilene. A close pavilion on deck, with a curtain before it; Pericles within it, reclined on a couch. A barge lying beside the Tyrian vessel.
Enter two Sailors, one belonging to the Tyrian vessel, the other to the barge; to them HELICANUS.

sp.speaker: Tyrian Sailor
sp.l: Where is lord Helicanus? he can resolve you.
O, here he is.
Sir, there is a barge put off from Mytilene,
And in it is Lysimachus the governor,
Who craves to come aboard. What is your will?

sp.speaker: Helicanus
sp.l: That he have his. Call up some gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Tyrian Sailor
sp.l: Ho, gentlemen! my lord calls. Enter two or three Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: First Gentleman
sp.l: Doth your lordship call?

sp.speaker: Helicanus
sp.l: Gentlemen, there is some of worth would come aboard;
I pray, greet him fairly. The Gentlemen and the two Sailors descend, and go on board the barge. Enter, from thence, LYSIMACHUS and Lords; with the Gentlemen and the two Sailors.

sp.speaker: Tyrian Sailor
sp.l: Sir,
This is the man that can, in aught you would,
Resolve you.

sp.speaker: Lysimachus
sp.l: Hail, reverend sir! the gods preserve you!

sp.speaker: Helicanus
sp.l: And you, to outlive the age I am,
And die as I would do.

sp.speaker: Lysimachus
sp.l: You wish me well.
Being on shore, honouring of Neptune's triumphs,
Seeing this goodly vessel ride before us,
I made to it, to know of whence you are.

sp.speaker: Helicanus
sp.l: First, what is your place?

sp.speaker: Lysimachus
sp.l: I am the governor of this place you lie before.

sp.speaker: Helicanus
sp.l: Sir,
Our vessel is of Tyre, in it the king;
A man who for this three months hath not spoken
To any one, nor taken sustenance
But to prorogue his grief.

sp.speaker: Lysimachus
sp.l: Upon what ground is his distemperature?

sp.speaker: Helicanus
sp.l: 'Twould be too tedious to repeat;
But the main grief springs from the loss
Of a beloved daughter and a wife.

sp.speaker: Lysimachus
sp.l: May we not see him?

sp.speaker: Helicanus
sp.l: You may;
But bootless is your sight: he will not speak
To any.

sp.speaker: Lysimachus
sp.l: Yet let me obtain my wish.

sp.speaker: Helicanus
sp.l: Behold him. Pericles discovered.
This was a goodly person,
Till the disaster that, one mortal night,
Drove him to this.

sp.speaker: Lysimachus
sp.l: Sir king, all hail! the gods preserve you!
Hail, royal sir!

sp.speaker: Helicanus
sp.l: It is in vain; he will not speak to you.

sp.speaker: First Lord
sp.l: Sir,
We have a maid in Mytilene, I durst wager,
Would win some words of him.

sp.speaker: Lysimachus
sp.l: 'Tis well bethought.
She questionless with her sweet harmony
And other chosen attractions, would allure,
And make a battery through his deafened parts,
Which now are midway stopped:
She is all happy as the fairest of all,
And, with her fellow maids, is now upon
The leafy shelter that abuts against
The island's side. Whispers a Lord, who goes off in the barge of Lysimachus.

sp.speaker: Helicanus
sp.l: Sure, all effectless; yet nothing we'll omit
That bears recovery's name. But, since your kindness
We have stretched thus far, let us beseech you
That for our gold we may provision have,
Wherein we are not destitute for want,
But weary for the staleness.

sp.speaker: Lysimachus
sp.l: O, sir, a courtesy
Which if we should deny, the most just god
For every graff would send a caterpillar,
And so inflict our province. Yet once more
Let me entreat to know at large the cause
Of your king's sorrow.

sp.speaker: Helicanus
sp.l: Sit, sir, I will recount it to you:
But, see, I am prevented. Re-enter, from the barge, Lord, with MARINA and a young Lady.

sp.speaker: Lysimachus
sp.l: O, here's
The lady that I sent for. Welcome, fair one!
Is't not a goodly presence?

sp.speaker: Helicanus
sp.l: She's a gallant lady.

sp.speaker: Lysimachus
sp.l: She's such a one, that, were I well assured
Came of a gentle kind and noble stock,
I'ld wish no better choice, and think me rarely to wed.
Fair one, all goodness that consists in beauty
Expect even here, where is a kingly patient:
If that thy prosperous and artificial feat
Can draw him but to answer thee in aught,
Thy sacred physic shall receive such pay
As thy desires can wish.

sp.speaker: Marina
sp.l: Sir, I will use
My utmost skill in his recovery,
Provided
That none but I and my companion maid
Be suffered to come near him.

sp.speaker: Lysimachus
sp.l: Come, let us leave her;
And the gods make her prosperous! Marina sings.

sp.speaker: Lysimachus
sp.l: Marked he your music?

sp.speaker: Marina
sp.l: No, nor looked on us.

sp.speaker: Lysimachus
sp.l: See, she will speak to him.

sp.speaker: Marina
sp.l: Hail, sir! my lord, lend ear.

sp.speaker: Pericles
sp.l: Hum, ha!

sp.speaker: Marina
sp.l: I am a maid,
My lord, that ne'er before invited eyes,
But have been gazed on like a comet: she speaks,
My lord, that, may be, hath endured a grief
Might equal yours, if both were justly weighed.
Though wayward fortune did malign my state,
My derivation was from ancestors
Who stood equivalent with mighty kings:
But time hath rooted out my parentage,
And to the world and awkward casualties
But there is something glows upon my cheek,
And whispers in mine ear âGo not till he speak.â

sp.speaker: Pericles
sp.l: My fortunes â parentage â good parentage â
To equal mine! â was it not thus? what say you?

sp.speaker: Marina
sp.l: I said, my lord, if you did know my parentage,
You would not do me violence.

sp.speaker: Pericles
sp.l: I do think so. Pray you, turn your eyes upon me.
You're like something that â What countrywoman?
Here of these shores?

sp.speaker: Marina
sp.l: No, nor of any shores:
Yet I was mortally brought forth, and am
No other than I appear.

sp.speaker: Pericles
sp.l: I am great with woe, and shall deliver weeping.
My dearest wife was like this maid, and such a one
My daughter might have been: my queen's square brows;
Her stature to an inch; as wand-like straight;
As silver-voiced; her eyes as jewel-like
And cased as richly; in pace another Juno;
Who starves the ears she feeds, and makes them hungry,
The more she gives them speech. Where do you live?

sp.speaker: Marina
sp.l: Where I am but a stranger: from the deck
You may discern the place.

sp.speaker: Pericles
sp.l: Where were you bred?
And how achieved you these endowments, which
You make more rich to owe?

sp.speaker: Marina
sp.l: If I should tell my history, it would seem
Like lies disdained in the reporting.

sp.speaker: Pericles
sp.l: Prithee, speak:
Falseness cannot come from thee; for thou look'st
Modest as Justice, and thou seem'st a palace
For the crowned Truth to dwell in: I will believe thee,
And make my senses credit thy relation
To points that seem impossible; for thou look'st
Like one I loved indeed. What were thy friends?
Didst thou not say, when I did push thee back â
Which was when I perceived thee â that thou camest
From good descending?

sp.speaker: Marina
sp.l: So indeed I did.

sp.speaker: Pericles
sp.l: Report thy parentage. I think thou saidst
Thou hadst been tossed from wrong to injury,
And that thou thought'st thy griefs might equal mine,
If both were opened.

sp.speaker: Marina
sp.l: Some such thing
I said, and said no more but what my thoughts
Did warrant me was likely.

sp.speaker: Pericles
sp.l: Tell thy story;
If thine considered prove the thousandth part
Of my endurance, thou art a man, and I
Have suffered like a girl: yet thou dost look
Like Patience gazing on kings' graves, and smiling
Extremity out of act. What were thy friends?
How lost thou them? Thy name, my most kind virgin?
Recount, I do beseech thee: come, sit by me.

sp.speaker: Marina
sp.l: My name is Marina.

sp.speaker: Pericles
sp.l: O, I am mocked,
And thou by some incensed god sent hither
To make the world to laugh at me.

sp.speaker: Marina
sp.l: Patience, good sir,
Or here I'll cease.

sp.speaker: Pericles
sp.l: Nay, I'll be patient.
Thou little know'st how thou dost startle me,
To call thyself Marina.

sp.speaker: Marina
sp.l: The name
Was given me by one that had some power,
My father, and a king.

sp.speaker: Pericles
sp.l: How! a king's daughter?
And called Marina?

sp.speaker: Marina
sp.l: You said you would believe me;
But, not to be a troubler of your peace,
I will end here.

sp.speaker: Pericles
sp.l: But are you flesh and blood?
Have you a working pulse? and are no fairy?
Motion! Well; speak on. Where were you born?
And wherefore called Marina?

sp.speaker: Marina
sp.l: Called Marina
For I was born at sea.

sp.speaker: Pericles
sp.l: At sea! what mother?

sp.speaker: Marina
sp.l: My mother was the daughter of a king;
Who died the minute I was born,
As my good nurse Lychorida hath oft
Delivered weeping.

sp.speaker: Pericles
sp.l: O, stop there a little! Aside
This is the rarest dream that e'er dulled sleep
Did mock sad fools withal: this cannot be:
My daughter â buried! Well: where were you bred?
I'll hear you more, to the bottom of your story,
And never interrupt you.

sp.speaker: Marina
sp.l: You scorn: believe me, 'twere best I did give o'er.

sp.speaker: Pericles
sp.l: I will believe you by the syllable
Of what you shall deliver. Yet, give me leave:
How came you in these parts? where were you bred?

sp.speaker: Marina
sp.l: The king my father did in Tarsus leave me;
Till cruel Cleon, with his wicked wife,
Did seek to murder me: and having wooed
A villain to attempt it, who having drawn to do't,
A crew of pirates came and rescued me;
Brought me to Mytilene. But, good sir,
Whither will you have me? Why do you weep? It may be,
You think me an impostor: no, good faith;
I am the daughter to King Pericles,
If good King Pericles be.

sp.speaker: Pericles
sp.l: Ho, Helicanus!

sp.speaker: Helicanus
sp.l: Calls my lord?

sp.speaker: Pericles
sp.l: Thou art a grave and noble counsellor,
Most wise in general: tell me, if thou canst,
What this maid is, or what is like to be,
That thus hath made me weep?

sp.speaker: Helicanus
sp.l: I know not; but
Here's the regent, sir, of Mytilene
Speaks nobly of her.

sp.speaker: Lysimachus
sp.l: She never would tell
Her parentage; being demanded that,
She would sit still and weep.

sp.speaker: Pericles
sp.l: O Helicanus, strike me, honoured sir;
Give me a gash, put me to present pain;
Lest this great sea of joys rushing upon me
o'erbear the shores of my mortality,
And drown me with their sweetness. O, come hither,
Thou that beget'st him that did thee beget;
Thou that wast born at sea, buried at Tarsus,
And found at sea again! O Helicanus,
Down on thy knees, thank the holy gods as loud
As thunder threatens us: this is Marina.
What was thy mother's name? tell me but that,
For truth can never be confirmed enough,
Though doubts did ever sleep.

sp.speaker: Marina
sp.l: First, sir, I pray,
What is your title?

sp.speaker: Pericles
sp.l: I am Pericles of Tyre: but tell me now
My drowned queen's name, as in the rest you said
Thou hast been godlike perfect,
The heir of kingdoms and another life
To Pericles thy father.

sp.speaker: Marina
sp.l: Is it no more to be your daughter than
To say my mother's name was Thaisa?
Thaisa was my mother, who did end
The minute I began.

sp.speaker: Pericles
sp.l: Now, blessing on thee! rise; thou art my child.
Give me fresh garments. Mine own, Helicanus;
She is not dead at Tarsus, as she should have been,
By savage Cleon: she shall tell thee all;
When thou shalt kneel, and justify in knowledge
She is thy very princess. Who is this?

sp.speaker: Helicanus
sp.l: Sir, 'tis the governor of Mytilene,
Who, hearing of your melancholy state,
Did come to see you.

sp.speaker: Pericles
sp.l: I embrace you.
Give me my robes. I am wild in my beholding.
O heavens bless my girl! But, hark, what music?
Tell Helicanus, my Marina, tell him
o'er, point by point, for yet he seems to dote,
How sure you are my daughter. But, what music?

sp.speaker: Helicanus
sp.l: My lord, I hear none.

sp.speaker: Pericles
sp.l: None!
The music of the spheres! List, my Marina.

sp.speaker: Lysimachus
sp.l: It is not good to cross him; give him way.

sp.speaker: Pericles
sp.l: Rarest sounds! Do ye not hear?

sp.speaker: Lysimachus
sp.l: Music, my lord, I hear. Music.

sp.speaker: Pericles
sp.l: Most heavenly music!
It nips me unto listening, and thick slumber
Hangs upon mine eyes: let me rest. Sleeps.

sp.speaker: Lysimachus
sp.l: A pillow for his head:
So, leave him all. Well, my companion friends,
If this but answer to my just belief,
I'll well remember you. Exeunt all but Pericles. DIANA appears to PERICLES as in a vision.

sp.speaker: Diana
sp.l: My temple stands in Ephesus: hie thee thither,
And do upon mine altar sacrifice.
There, when my maiden priests are met together,
Before the people all,
Reveal how thou at sea didst lose thy wife:
To mourn thy crosses, with thy daughter's, call
And give them repetition to the life.
Or perform my bidding, or thou livest in woe;
Do't, and happy; by my silver bow!
Awake, and tell thy dream. Disappears.

sp.speaker: Pericles
sp.l: Celestial Dian, goddess argentine,
I will obey thee. Helicanus! Re-enter HELICANUS, LYSIMACHUS, and MARINA.

sp.speaker: Helicanus
sp.l: Sir?

sp.speaker: Pericles
sp.l: My purpose was for Tarsus, there to strike
The inhospitable Cleon; but I am
For other service first: toward Ephesus
Turn our blown sails; eftsoons I'll tell thee why. To Lysimachus
Shall we refresh us, sir, upon your shore,
And give you gold for such provision
As our intents will need?

sp.speaker: Lysimachus
sp.l: Sir,
With all my heart; and, when you come ashore,
I have another suit.

sp.speaker: Pericles
sp.l: You shall prevail,
Were it to woo my daughter; for it seems
You have been noble towards her.

sp.speaker: Lysimachus
sp.l: Sir, lend me your arm.

sp.speaker: Pericles
sp.l: Come, my Marina. Exeunt.

div.head: Act 5, Scene 2
div.stage: Enter GOWER, before the temple of DIANA at Ephesus.

sp.speaker: Gower
sp.l: Now our sands are almost run;
More a little, and then dumb.
This, my last boon, give me,
For such kindness must relieve me,
That you aptly will suppose
What pageantry, what feats, what shows,
What minstrelsy, and pretty din,
The regent made in Mytilene
To greet the king. So he thrived,
That he is promised to be wived
To fair Marina; but in no wise
Till he had done his sacrifice,
As Dian bade: whereto being bound,
The interim, pray you, all confound.
In feathered briefness sails are filled,
And wishes fall out as they're willed.
At Ephesus, the temple see,
Our king and all his company.
That he can hither come so soon,
Is by your fancy's thankful doom. Exit.

div.head: Act 5, Scene 3
div.stage: The temple of Diana at Ephesus; THAISA standing near the altar, as high priestess; a number of Virgins on each side; CERIMON and other Inhabitants of Ephesus attending.
Enter PERICLES, wlith his train; LYSIMACHUS, HELICANUS, MARINA, and a Lady.

sp.speaker: Pericles
sp.l: Hail, Dian! to perform thy just command,
I here confess myself the king of Tyre;
Who, frighted from my country, did wed
At Pentapolis the fair Thaisa.
At sea in childbed died she, but brought forth
A maid-child called Marina; whom, O goddess,
Wears yet thy silver livery. She at Tarsus
Was nursed with Cleon; who at fourteen years
He sought to murder: but her better stars
Brought her to Mytilene; 'gainst whose shore
Riding, her fortunes brought the maid aboard us,
Where, by her own most clear remembrance, she
Made known herself my daughter.

sp.speaker: Thaisa
sp.l: Voice and favour!
You are, you are â O royal Pericles! Faints.

sp.speaker: Pericles
sp.l: What means the nun? she dies! help, gentlemen!

sp.speaker: Cerimon
sp.l: Noble sir,
If you have told Diana's altar true,
This is your wife.

sp.speaker: Pericles
sp.l: Reverend appearer, no;
I threw her overboard with these very arms.

sp.speaker: Cerimon
sp.l: Upon this coast, I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Pericles
sp.l: 'Tis most certain.

sp.speaker: Cerimon
sp.l: Look to the lady; O, she's but o'erjoyed.
Early in blustering morn this lady was
Thrown upon this shore. I oped the coffin,
Found there rich jewels; recovered her, and placed her
Here in Diana's temple.

sp.speaker: Pericles
sp.l: May we see them?

sp.speaker: Cerimon
sp.l: Great sir, they shall be brought you to my house,
Whither I invite you. Look, Thaisa is
Recovered.

sp.speaker: Thaisa
sp.l: O, let me look!
If he be none of mine, my sanctity
Will to my sense bend no licentious ear,
But curb it, spite of seeing. O, my lord,
Are you not Pericles? Like him you spake,
Like him you are: did you not name a tempest,
A birth, and death?

sp.speaker: Pericles
sp.l: The voice of dead Thaisa!

sp.speaker: Thaisa
sp.l: That Thaisa am I, supposed dead
And drowned.

sp.speaker: Pericles
sp.l: Immortal Dian!

sp.speaker: Thaisa
sp.l: Now I know you better.
When we with tears parted Pentapolis,
The king my father gave you such a ring. Shows a ring.

sp.speaker: Pericles
sp.l: This, this: no more, you gods! your present kindness
Makes my past miseries sports: you shall do well,
That on the touching of her lips I may
Melt and no more be seen. O, come, be buried
A second time within these arms.

sp.speaker: Marina
sp.l: My heart
Leaps to be gone into my mother's bosom. Kneels to Thaisa.

sp.speaker: Pericles
sp.l: Look, who kneels here! Flesh of thy flesh, Thaisa;
Thy burden at the sea, and called Marina
For she was yielded there.

sp.speaker: Thaisa
sp.l: Blest, and mine own!

sp.speaker: Helicanus
sp.l: Hail, madam, and my queen!

sp.speaker: Thaisa
sp.l: I know you not.

sp.speaker: Pericles
sp.l: You have heard me say, when I did fly from Tyre,
I left behind an ancient substitute:
Can you remember what I called the man?
I have named him oft.

sp.speaker: Thaisa
sp.l: 'Twas Helicanus then.

sp.speaker: Pericles
sp.l: Still confirmation:
Embrace him, dear Thaisa; this is he.
Now do I long to hear how you were found;
How possibly preserved; and who to thank,
Besides the gods, for this great miracle.

sp.speaker: Thaisa
sp.l: Lord Cerimon, my lord; this man,
Through whom the gods have shown their power; that can
From first to last resolve you.

sp.speaker: Pericles
sp.l: Reverend sir,
The gods can have no mortal officer
More like a god than you. Will you deliver
How this dead queen relives?

sp.speaker: Cerimon
sp.l: I will, my lord.
Beseech you, first go with me to my house,
Where shall be shown you all was found with her;
How she came placed here in the temple;
No needful thing omitted.

sp.speaker: Pericles
sp.l: Pure Dian, I bless thee for thy vision, and
Will offer night-oblations to thee. Thaisa,
This prince, the fair-betrothed of your daughter,
Shall marry her at Pentapolis. And now,
This ornament
Makes me look dismal will I clip to form;
And what this fourteen years no razor touched,
To grace thy marriage-day, I'll beautify.

sp.speaker: Thaisa
sp.l: Lord Cerimon hath letters of good credit, sir,
My father's dead.

sp.speaker: Pericles
sp.l: Heavens make a star of him! Yet there, my queen,
We'll celebrate their nuptials, and ourselves
Will in that kingdom spend our following days:
Our son and daughter shall in Tyrus reign.
Lord Cerimon, we do our longing stay
To hear the rest untold: sir, lead's the way. Exeunt.

div.head: Act 5, Chorus 2
div.stage: Enter GOWER.

sp.speaker: Gower
sp.l: In Antiochus and his daughter you have heard
Of monstrous lust the due and just reward:
In Pericles, his queen and daughter, seen,
Although assailed with fortune fierce and keen,
Virtue preserved from fell destruction's blast,
Led on by heaven, and crowned with joy at last:
In Helicanus may you well descry
A figure of truth, of faith, of loyalty:
In reverend Cerimon there well appears
The worth that learned charity aye wears:
For wicked Cleon and his wife, when fame
Had spread his cursed deed, the honoured name
Of Pericles to rage the city turn,
That him and his they in his palace burn;
The gods for murder seemed so content
To punish â although not done, but meant.
So, on your patience evermore attending,
New joy wait on you! Here our play has ending. Exit.
